The sub-chapter on the circular sitting mat

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū kāyaṁ vivaritvā antaraghare gacchanti …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū kāyam vivaritvā antara ghare gacchanti pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were walking in inhabited areas with their bodies uncovered. …

analyzed: su paṭicchannaḥ antaraghare gamissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will walk in inhabited areas with my body well-covered,’ this is how you should train.”
One should walk in inhabited areas with one’s body well-covered.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca kāyaṁ vivaritvā antaraghare gacchati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca kāyam vivaritvā antaraghare gacchati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, walks in an inhabited area with his body uncovered, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
There is no offense if it is unintentional,
if he is not thinking,🔽if he does not know,🔽if he is sick,🔽if there are dangers,
if he is the first offender.🔽The third training rule is finished.
